abstract.text: A static ordered collection of objects.

Creates and returns an array containing a given object.

Initializes a newly allocated array by placing in it the objects contained in a given array.

as the source of data objects for the array.

Returns an enumerator object that lets you access each object in the array.
Returns an enumerator object that lets you access each object in the array, in reverse order.
Returns the lowest index whose corresponding array value is equal to a given object.
Returns the lowest index within a specified range whose corresponding array value is equal to a given object .
Returns the lowest index whose corresponding array value is identical to a given object.
Returns the lowest index within a specified range whose corresponding array value is equal to a given object .
Returns the index of the first object in the array that passes a test in a given block.
Returns the index of an object in the array that passes a test in a given block for a given set of enumeration options.
Returns the index, from a given set of indexes, of the first object in the array that passes a test in a given block for a given set of enumeration options.
Returns the indexes of objects in the array that pass a test in a given block.
Returns the indexes of objects in the array that pass a test in a given block for a given set of enumeration options.
Returns the indexes, from a given set of indexes, of objects in the array that pass a test in a given block for a given set of enumeration options.
Sends to each object in the array the message identified by a given selector, starting with the first object and continuing through the array to the last object.
Sends the
message to each object in the array, starting with the first object and continuing through the array to the last object.
Executes a given block using each object in the array, starting with the first object and continuing through the array to the last object.
Executes a given block using each object in the array with the specified options.
Executes a given block using the objects in the array at the specified indexes.
Returns the first object contained in the receiving array that’s equal to an object in another given array.
Compares the receiving array to another array.
Returns a new array that is a copy of the receiving array with a given object added to the end.
Returns a new array that is a copy of the receiving array with the objects contained in another array added to the end.
Evaluates a given predicate against each object in the receiving array and returns a new array containing the objects for which the predicate returns true.
Returns a new array containing the receiving array’s elements that fall within the limits specified by a given range.

inlineContent.text: and its subclass
manage ordered collections of objects called
arrays
creates static arrays, and
creates dynamic arrays. You can use arrays when you need an ordered collection of objects.
is “toll-free bridged” with its Core Foundation counterpart,
. See
for more information on toll-free bridging.

content.text: Creating NSArray Objects Using Array Literals

inlineContent.text: In addition to the provided initializers, such as
, you can create an
object using an
array literal
In Objective-C, the compiler generates code that makes an underlying call to the
method.
You should not terminate the list of objects with
when using this literal syntax, and in fact
is an invalid value. For more information about object literals in Objective-C, see
in
In Swift, the
class conforms to the
protocol, which allows it to be initialized with array literals. For more information about object literals in Swift, see
in
In addition to the provided instance methods, such as
, you can access
values by their indexes using
subscripting
There is typically little reason to subclass
. The class does well what it is designed to do—maintain an ordered collection of objects. But there are situations where a custom
object might come in handy. Here are a few possibilities:
Changing how
stores the elements of its collection. You might do this for performance reasons or for better compatibility with legacy code.
Acquiring more information about what is happening to the collection (for example, statistics gathering).
Any subclass of
must
override the primitive instance methods
and
. These methods must operate on the backing store that you provide for the elements of the collection. For this backing store you can use a static array, a standard
object, or some other data type or mechanism. You may also choose to override, partially or fully, any other
method for which you want to provide an alternative implementation.

You might want to implement an initializer for your subclass that is suited to the backing store that the subclass is managing. If you do, your initializer must invoke one of the designated initializers of the
class, either
or
. The
class adopts the
, and
protocols; custom subclasses of
should override the methods in these protocols as necessary.
Remember that

is the public interface for a class cluster and what this entails for your subclass. You must provide the storage for your subclass and implement the primitive methods that directly act on that storage.
Before making a custom subclass of
, investigate
and the corresponding Core Foundation type,
. Because
and
are “toll-free bridged,” you can substitute a
object for a
object in your code (with appropriate casting). Although they are corresponding types,
and
do not have identical interfaces or implementations, and you can sometimes do things with
that you cannot easily do with
. For example,
provides a set of callbacks, some of which are for implementing custom retain-release behavior. If you specify
implementations for these callbacks, you can easily get a non-retaining array.
If the behavior you want to add supplements that of the existing class, you could write a category on
. Keep in mind, however, that this category will be in effect for all instances of
that you use, and this might have unintended consequences. Alternatively, you could use composition to achieve the desired behavior.
